FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Plan describes procedures implemented by Wilbur-Ellis Company LLC Tilma, WA ("Wilbur-Ellis") to prevent accidental releases of ammonia that could cause harm to the public and the environment from short-term exposures.  The Plan includes an analysis of the potential offsite consequences of an accidental release, a five-year accident history, and a release prevention and emergency response program.  



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Wilbur-Ellis has implemented release prevention and emergency response procedures to minimize the potential for accidental releases of hazardous materials.  Emergency response procedures including evacuation procedures and notification procedures have been implemented by Wilbur-Ellis.  In addition, Wilbur-Ellis has developed operating procedures and preventative maintenance activities to reduce the likelihood of accidental releases.



This Plan and the emergency response procedures document the accidental release prevention, safety, and emergency policies in place at Wilbur-Ellis.



Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Wilbur-Ellis Tilma is located at 51 Stateline Road in Tekoa, Washington (the "facility").  Wilbur-Ellis is a retailer of fertilizer in the form of anhydrous ammonia stored under pressure.  There are two anhydrous ammonia storage tanks located at the facility with a capacity of approximately 12,500 gallons each.  The anhydrous ammonia is transferred from the storage tank into tender trucks.  There are three tender trucks with 2,000-gallon tanks and one tender truck with one 2,100 gallon tank.  There are also three applicator tanks onsite with a capacity of 750, 1000, and 2000 gallons respectively.  The contents of the tender trucks and/or applicator tanks are sold and delivered to the local farming community for use as fertilizer.  



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

Wilbur-Ellis has developed and implemented thi

s Plan with the objective of complying with the requirements and guidelines set forth by the Federal Risk Management Plan program.  The Plan's purpose is to enhance the facility's existing safety programs implemented at the site to reduce the possibility of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia that could cause harm to employees, the public and the environment.  The emergency response program, documented in the emergency response procedures, includes accidental release prevention and chemical specific prevention steps.



Wilbur-Ellis ensures that equipment meets the appropriate industry standards prior to use.  Wilbur-Ellis implements operating procedures and maintenance procedures in accordance with manufacturer and industry specifications to prevent accidental releases at the facility.  Chemical specific prevention steps implemented at the site include excess flow valves, pressure relief valves, emergency shut off valves with cables that run along the length of the horizontal storage tanks for quick access, and ammonia training for personnel.

 

Five-Year Accident History

There have been no qualifying accidents involving ammonia in the five-year period prior to the completion of this Plan.



Emergency Response Program

The facility coordinates with the Tekoa Fire Department ("fire department") regarding specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  The facility has established emergency evacuation procedures to evacuate the site and notify the appropriate agencies regarding a release.  The facility's emergency response program is documented in the facility's Emergency Response Procedures.  The emergency procedures contain the following key elements:



              1. Emergency response notification procedures.

              2. Facility evacuation procedures.

              3. Emergency response coordination and regulatory notification.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Plans to improve safety at the facility

were developed based on the results of compliance audits, hazard reviews, and a Risk Management Plan (RMP) site inspection conducted by an outside contractor.  The Branch Manger is currently working on an implementation schedule for the recommended actions.  Recommended actions include the following:



1. Coordinating with delivery contractors to obtain copies of their operating procedures, safety training, and other relevant certifications.  Also involving contractors in tailgate site safety meetings to educate them about site specific hazards and emergency evacuation procedures. 

2. Updating operating procedures to match P&ID drawing for site system.  

3. Updating operating procedures to include site specific procedural steps and maintenance actives.
